transcript:
were woodcutting, and, al- lowing the French to pass him, had made a bayonet charge with two battalions and had broken up the French troops. 
"When I saw, your excellency, that their first battalion was disorganized, I stopped in the road and thought: 'I'll let them come on and will meet them with the fire of the whole bat- talion' and that's what I did." 
The general had so wished to do this and was so sorry he had not managed to do it that it seemed to him as if it had really happened. Perh
